 1. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. ENERGY SOURCES AND USES 1.01 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is short of energy resources. It has lignite, which is mostly used to generate electricity, and hydropower; which together are sufficient to make the country more or less self-sufficient in electricity, though it exchanges electricity with surrounding countries. There is also extensive use of firewood. Altogether domestic energy sources are about 60% of energy supplies. The country totally lacks oil, gas or high quality coal resources and as a result imports around 40% of its energy consumption. Most of these imports are crude oil when the refinery is running or petroleum products when the refinery is not running. There are also normally small imports of coke for the steel mills and the country is just beginning the importation of Russian Natural Gas. Over the period 1990-96 energy imports amounted to about 11- 16% of total imports depending on the strength of the economy and any build-up or run- down of inventories which may be occurring. 1.02 The energy balances available for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia concentrate on sources of energy and provide very limited information on energy use. The table below shows the sources of energy for 1996. In that year about 41% of energy was imported, mostly petroleum products. The main domestic sources of energy are: 1) lignite, which is primarily used to generate electricity; 2) firewood, which is used extensively by households for heating and cooking; and 3) hydropower. Hydropower in 1996 was about 4.8% of energy supply and 23% of electricity production (5.2x1o TJ).  2 B. ENERGY INTENSITY/CONSERVATION 1.03 The economy of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is more energy intensive than most West European Countries, though not as energy intensive as those countries which were members of the former Soviet bloc. For example the ratio of GDP ($) produced to energy consumed (kilograms of oil equivalent) is about 1.5 $/Kg in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia compared with 3-6 which would be typical of Western Europe or 0.4-0.6 which would be typical of Eastern Europe. Energy intensiveness in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is due to four primary factors. First, the share of industry in GDP or GSP is relatively high, which is true of most ex-socialist countries. Second, much of the industry is inherently quite energy intensive including steel, non-ferrous metals, and cement. Third, the industries in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia use less energy efficient technology than their Western counterparts. Finally, houses are poorly insulated. 1.04 Thus, the potential for energy conservation in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is substantial and has been recognized by the Government. As the economic transition continues, companies are being privatized and budget constraints are becoming harder for the remaining Government owned companies. As a result, industries are now becoming very conscious of their energy costs and have developed a number of larger energy saving investments. Financing of these investments, however, is a problem due to the poor condition of the Macedonian Banking System and uncertainty about the long run viability of some of the companies involved. In fact, these investments should generally not be undertaken until it is clear that the companies involved are financially viable in a market economy. 1.05 Also since 1988, the Government has had a modest program, administered by the Ministry of Economy, to increase energy efficiency. This program consists of a competition held twice a year, where enterprises compete to receive small government loans on favorable terms for energy saving investments. However, most investments in industry are too large for the above program. C. SECTORORGANIZATION 1.06 The energy sector is currently largely owned by the Government, with the principal sectoral companies being: the power company, Elektrostopanstvo na Makedonija (ESM); the Skopje Refinery; the Skopje District Heating Company; and Makpetrol (the petroleum products distribution company). ESM is wholly and directly owned by the Government, while the majority of the shares in the Refinery and Skopje District Heating Company are socially owned with a small share holding by the employees. These socially owned shares are left from the previous SFRY self- management system. They are owned by the Government, which can sell them, but the companies are self-managing. Makpetrol, on the other hand, is now more than half
 3 privately owned and is officially an independent company. Government controls over the energy sector are shared by several ministries and differ somewhat between the various entities. The key institutional relationships are as follows: * The Council of Ministers sets prices of petroleum products and electricity and is expected to approve natural gas prices. It makes top management appointments for ESM and ratifies major investments by ESM. * The Ministry of Economy has principal oversight responsibility for the energy sector and reviews and approves the investment plans of ESM. It recommends to the Council of Ministers the tariffs for electricity and petroleum product prices, based upon the proposals of the interested companies. It will set natural gas prices, subject to the approval of the Council'of Ministers. In the special case of district heating prices, the Ministry can approve these prices without the intervention of the Council of Ministers. It is involved in the selection of top management for ESM. * The Ministry of Development reviews and comments on major investment plans, especially those of ESM. This review is mostly to see that the plans are consistent with the overall investment plan of the country and with the country's potential financing capacity from internal and external sources. It can also review and comment on pricing proposals. 3 The Ministry of Finance can review and comment on pricing proposals and reviews and comments on investments when Government Guarantees are required for debt financing. 1.07 The general procedure in the sector to obtain approval for an increase in prices (except for district heating, see above) is first for the sectoral company to submit a formal request with a detailed explanation. The proposed price increase goes to the Ministry of Economy for review with other Ministries commenting on it if they choose. After this review, the request is sent to the Council of Ministers for action. This system has worked satisfactorily in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, since the Council of Ministers has generally acted responsibly. Moreover electricity prices, perhaps the most important prices, are set under a loan agreement between the EBRD and the Government to which the Council of Ministers has generally adhered. -1.08 The Government needs overtime to privatize the sectoral companies (along with most of the industry of the country). The first step has been taken with the recent privatization of Makpetrol through a management and employee buy-out. The refinery should also be privatized if that is feasible given its uncertain outlook. Less urgently, the three "natural monopolies", the Skopje District Heating Company, ESM and the gas transmission and distribution company should be privatized. As these companies are being privatized the Government needs to ensure an adequate and transparent regulatory
 4 mechanism and facilitate the development of competition especially in petroleum retailing and in power generation. (See below.) D. LEGISLATION 1.09 Two key pieces of legislation that affect the energy sector are the Energy Law and the Law on Public Enterprises. The Energy Law, which has just been passed by Parliament, establishes a basis for the operation of energy companies, though it is very broad (covering all energy) and somewhat vague on important issues while very specific on other minor issues. Nevertheless it clearly establishes the important principle that all activities in the energy sector can be carried out by both public and private, foreign and domestic individuals and organizations, though licenses would be required. Specifically it allows these individuals and organizations to engage in production, transmission and distribution of electricity as well as natural gas and petroleum. It also requires, inter alia, the Government to establish and implement a methodology for setting electricity prices. 1.10 The Government, especially the Ministry of Economy, will be heavily involved in drawing up regulations to implement the Energy Law. The Ministry is currently working on a cost-based methodology for setting electricity prices, which it would implement through a regulation approved by the Council of Ministers. It is also working on regulations which would deal with the pricing system which ESM would use to pay for the electricity it purchases from independent power producers ( IPPs) or the prices IPPs would pay for using ESM's transmission network. This is important since there is significant potential for IPPs both in the form of small scale hydropower plants and in the form of cogeneration from industrial facilities. This potential has not, however, been exploited and needs to be encouraged. This project therefore seeks to encourage IPPs by reaching agreement with the Government that it will adopt regulations under the Energy Law acceptable to the Bank governing the operations of IPPs by December 31,1998. Furthermore, a GEF project is under preparation which would provide grant funding to allow the development of two or three small hydropower sites to serve as pilot IPPs. 1.11 The Law on Public Enterprises regulates various aspects of these enterprises including: 1) management, 2) statutes, 3) financial reporting, 4) regulations regarding strikes, and 5) state control over public enterprises. Public enterprises are autonomous organizations and can be organized as joint stock companies. If they are organized in that manner they can have minority private ownership. They are also separate legal entities which can own assets and have liabilities. They are to be financially independent and not funded by the Government budget. They have a Managing Board, a General Manager and a Supervisory Board. The Government appointed Managing Board is the chief governing and decision making body of the enterprise. These provisions are consistent with those in many other countries and do not pose any major issues.

GENERAL 2.01 Electricity is the most important form of energy used in the country with the majority of the population using it not only for lighting and cooking, but also to a significant extent for heating. Production of electricity in 1996 was 6.17 Twh with 4.73 Twh supplied by thermal power plants and 1.44 Twh supplied by hydropower plants - mainly for peaking. Domestic consumption of electricity was 5.2 Twh and losses, most of which were in distribution were .785 Twh. There were also small net exports. Of the total consumption, 2.5 Twh or 48% were sales to households while the rest were sales primarily to industry but also commerce and government. Of the total sales of electricity to industry, around 1.5 Twh are at high voltage to the largest industrial companies. There are 12 of these companies and they include steel plants, non-ferrous metals plants, chemical works, the refinery etc. The rest of the industrial sales as well as sales to government and commerce are at lower voltage. The system is winter peaking, due to the use of electricity for heating, with a peak in 1996 of 1145 MW and a minimum load of 334MW. B. BACKGROLIND 2.02 Consumption of electricity in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia grew until the early part of this decade. Over the entire period 1970-1996 the growth rate was 4.2%, while for the shorter period of 1983 to 1996 it was only 1.0%. During the past several years, moreover, electricity consumption has grown very slowly as the country entered a period of rapid economic contraction due to major external shocks - mostly connected to the dissolution of the Yugoslav Federation. These included losses of annual transfers from the central Government which had amounted to 5-10% of GSP, loss of foreign exchange reserves totaling over $1 billion held at the Central Bank in Belgrade, and the loss of export markets due to the economic sanctions imposed by the UN on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro). This was aggravated by the Greek embargo in 1994-95 which disrupted trade. These factors lead to major dislocations in the economy with a drop in GDP of about 30% between 1990 and 1995. Electricity consumption, however, did not decline anywhere near as much as GDP in part because of a shift towards use of electricity (which is domestically produced) and away from petroleum products (which are imported) as the latter became less available and more expensive. The economy hit bottom in 1995 and began to recover in 1996. Moreover, electricity consumption began to recover even before the economy and rose in both 1995 and 1996, by about 3% per year. Most of the increase in consurnption came from households and other low voltage consumers, the latter consisting mostly of small industries and commercial establishments.

FIMJURE DEMAND 2.03 Electricity consumption is related to the growth of the economy, but is also impacted by external factors. Assuming the economy continues to recover and restructure and there are no further shocks, a reasonable assumption for GDP growth might be around 4-5% a year from 1998 to 2005. Initially electricity growth may tend to keep pace with GDP growth as industrial output rises and household incomes improve. In the intermediate term, however, electricity growth should be slower than GDP growth for at least three reasons. First, the structure of the economy should shift away from heavy industry especially metals, to lighter industry, agriculture and services and this shift should accelerate over time. Second, the remaining heavy industry should become more efficient in its use of electricity and energy due to the increase in energy prices, continued enforcement of hard budget constraints and the impact of privatization. Finally, the creation of a gas distribution system in Skopje , around the turn of the century, will shift about 50,000 households mostly from electric heating to gas heating. It will also cause some commercial and Governmental establishments to shift from electricity to gas. While the exact size of this shift is unkmown, the creation of the gas distribution system could reduce electricity consumption by around 0.5-.7 Twh. Taking these factors into account ESM's estimates of growth for the period 1997-2005 of around 3-4% in the nearer term slowing to 1.5-2.0% after 2002 would appear reasonable, though there are significant uncertainties involved in all of the assumptions above, especially the GDP forecast. The major generating units in the country are described briefly below. 2.06 The BITQLA power plant and adjacent mine is the biggest energy complex in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. It is located close to the town of Bitola in the southern part of the country. The power plant, with 675 MW of capacity, is a little under half the generating capacity in the country, but typically supplies about 70% of country electricity needs. This is because it: 1) is a base load plant, 2) uses local fuels and thus is little effected by trade disruptions, and 3) is relatively new with good availability. The power plant units were commissioned in 1982, 1984 and 1988 as Russian units of 210 MW. However, at fairly low cost, the plant expanded them to 225 MW units. The adjacent open-pit mine, Suvudol, produces about 6 million tonnes of lignite per year which mostly supplies the power plant. Lignite reserves at the Suvudol mine are adequate to last about 20 years. The plant is generally in good condition and well maintained.
 9 2.07 The NEGOTINO thermal power plant, located close to the town of Negotino, was constructed in 1978 and designed for two units of 210 MW each. The first unit was completed in March 1978 and the second unit was never started. The plant was designed to burn heavy fuel oil (9600 kcal/kg) but could be converted to natural gas (8000 kcal/m3) at low cost. For the past four years the plant was shut down due first to the lack of heavy fuel oil (during the Greek Embargo) and then to its relatively high cost. Currently it is on cold stand-by. 2.08 The OSLOMEJ power plant and lignite mine are located in the Western part of the country and have been in operation since 1980. The mine produces about 1.1 million tonnes of lignite per year which is used in the power plant which has one unit of 120 MW capacity. There is little potential for expansion at this time due to the limited life of the mine. 2.09 The MAVROVO hydro scheme (also called Tito-Gostivar) is composed of the powerhouses Vrutok, Vrben and Raven, the Mavrovo dam and reservoir and a network of feeder canals to catch the water coming from the nearby mountains. The first power house in line is Vrben at 12.8 MW. Water emerging from this power house goes into the multi-year Mavrovo reservoir and then to the two power stations of Vrutok and Raven that are supplied in series by the same penstock. The capacity of this hydro scheme is 182 MW, which is a little less than half of ESM's installed hydro capacity of 426 MW (including the small plants). This hydro scheme typically generates around 500 Gwh about 80% of which comes from the largest plant, Vrutok. Generation from this hydro scheme is typically just under 50% of the hydropower production in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and is used primarily for peaking purposes. The powerhouses in this scheme were built back in the 1950's and need to be rehabilitated in order to increase efficiency and reliability. 2.10 The GLOBOCICA hydro power plant is located in the southwest part of the country on the Black Drim river, 22 km North of the town of Struga. It has been in operation since 1965. Installed capacity is 42 MW and average annual output is around 187 Gwh. It also is in need rehabilitation. 2.11 The TIKVES hydro power plant is located on the Black River, not far from Kavadarci. The two first units have been in operation since 1968, and units 3 and 4 since 1981. Total installed capacity is 92 MW, and average annual generation is about 185 Gwh. The plant is primarily used for peaking purposes, though it is also run when irrigation water is needed downstream. Due to age, it is in need of rehabilitation. 2.12 The SPILJE hydro power plant is located on the Black Drim river downstream of Globocica. In operation since 1969, its installed capacity is 70.2 MW and the average annual generation is around 300 Gwh. The Derbar reservoir behind the Spilje dam has moderate storage capacity and the plant operates both as a base load unit and for peaking purposes. Again some rehabilitation is required.

IRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUITIQN 2.13 While the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia was part of Yugoslavia, its power system was part of Yugoslavia's electric utility association, JUGEL; which in turn was part of the Western European Electricity network, UCPTE. Thus, ESM was not designed to be a self sufficient utility but rather part of a regional (JUGEL) and international system (UCPTE). It would still gain very significantly from being part of a regional system and eventually re-establishing the physical link with UCPTE', which is currently severed because of the Yugoslav Civil War. An embryonic and informal regional system seems to be developing with Greece, Bulgaria, Romania, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro) and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia all coordinating and exchanging power. However, a well developed, formal system has not been established and in the short to intermediate term it is likely that the the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's Power System will not be part of a larger fully integrated electricity network and thus it will continue to need more domestic reserve capacity to provide spinning reserves and frequency control. Thus the role of the major hydropower plants, which provide peaking capacity, frequency control and spinning reserves, is further enhanced. 2.14 The Macedonian Dispatch Center was also designed to function as part of a regional and international system. More specifically it was one of the eight dispatch centers in the republics and provinces of Yugoslavia which worked in conjunction with the pool or Federation Dispatch Center in Belgrade, which in turn coordinated with UCPTE. An energy management system (EMS), financed by the Bank (Loan 2338- YU), was under construction for the integrated Yugoslav System when the Yugoslav Civil War broke out. As a result of the civil war the integrated Yugoslav System disappeared and now the Skopje dispatch center has to function in isolation. To do this most efficiently it needs some additional hardware, software and telecommunications equipment to improve control over and communication with the power plants especially with the hydropower plants. 2.15 On the whole the Macedonian Transmission system is in acceptable condition. The backbone of the system is the 400 KV line crossing the country from FR Yugoslavia to Greece and which linked Greece to UCPTE. In total there are 256 Km of 400 KV lines, 165 Km of 220 KV lines and 1500 km of 110 KV lines. A new transmission line from Bitola to Skopje, financed by EBRD, has recently been finished. 2.16 On the other hand, the distribution system in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is overloaded. It was built some years ago and carries more electricity than it was designed for. ELECTRICIT WPR-ICES 2.17 Electricity prices are set by the Government, but taking into account agreements with the IFIs on this issue. More specifically electricity prices are set by the Council of Ministers based on a request from ESM, through the Ministry of Economy. Under an EBRD Loan to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia a target pattern of real electricity price increases in German Marks (DEM) has been established which is then reinforced under the Bank's FESAC Credit. The Cabinet has generally adhered to these agreements. Expressed in German Pfennigs, the average electricity price rose from 5.9 Pfennigs/Kwh in 1994 to 6.1 Pfennigs in 1995 and to 6.55 in 1996. While prices rose about 10% in Denar terms in 1997, due to the devaluation of the Denar the average electricity price in Pfennigs actually declined slightly. EBRD is concerned about this since their covenant is to increase the price to 7.5 Pfennigs/Kwh and maintain it at that level. This price (7.5 Pfennigs/Kwh) is 4.2-5.4 US cents/Kwh depending on the Dollar/Mark exchange rate. While no study of long run marginal costs has yet been done, based on ESM's relatively low operating costs (around 3.5-4.0 US cents/Kwh) and the lack of need in the near term for additional generating capacity, it would appear that this price of 7.5 Pfennigs is probably not far from long run marginal costs. ( See para. 4.05). 2.18 The Macedonian tariff system is consistent with principles of economic pricing with differentiation by time of day, season, and voltage level and including capacity and energy charges. It also avoids one mistake that is standard in ex-socialist countries. This mistake is charging households and commercial establishments substantially less for electricity than industry, even though it costs more to supply them. In the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia households and commercial establishments are in fact charged more than industry. For example in 1996 the average price for electricity supplied to the largest industries, that is industries that receive electricity directly from the high voltage grid, was 0.93Dn/Kwh compared with an average price of 1.80 Dn/Kwh for households. 2.19 Households/Poyety Electricity represents about 4-5% of expenditures by households in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Almost all households are connected to the grid and electricity is overwhelmingly used for lighting and is the most common means of cooking. Electricity is less used for heating , with a substantial part of the heat used by households being provided by burning firewood or in Skopje by the Skopje District Heating System. While electricity is thus an important consumer item, the Government has not felt it necessary to provide special subsidies in this area. Rather the Government has relied on a social safety net consisting of redundancy payments, unemployment benefits, means tested income support and pensions. The possibility exists, however, that the Government might want to introduce a lifeline tariff system and this would depend largely on whether the Government decides that a lifeline tariff system would provide better targeting of subsidies to the very poor.
 12 G. ORGANIZATIONAL ISSUES 2.20 Role of Government. The power sector currently operates as a public monopoly, with ESM as the principal entity. As such it is classified as a public enterprise and falls under state control. The extent of state control is principally in the areas of investment planning, management selection and pricing. These activities are spread over several ministries and the Council of Ministers as described in para. 1.06 above. 2.21 Sector Organization. The Government of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, with the assistance of USAID, had a study undertaken of the organization of the electricity sector. This study was done by Arthur Andersen and Bechtel and looked primarily at the issue of whether the system should be unbundled or not. Their conclusion was that given the very small size of the system and the dominant role played by the Bitola power plant, unbundling is difficult and may not be suitable. These conclusions are appropriate. The primary benefit from unbundling is normally the creation of competition among power plants or groups of power plants to supply electricity. However, in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia there is one dominant power plant (Bitola), which would set the price and there would be little competition. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 3.01 This project through rehabilitating hydro-power plants, completing the EMS and starting the rehabilitation of the distribution system aims to achieve the following objectives. First, increase the efficiency of hydro-power generation. This would result in greater hydropower generation for any given amount of water and a resultant reduction in system costs and a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions due to reduced thermal generation. Secod, expand the generating capacity of the major hydro-power plants through rehabilitation. This should enable the country to better meet its peak electricity demands, help stabilize frequency and reduce the likelihood of brown-outs and black- outs. Third, increase system operating efficiency through completion of a modem Energy Management System (EMS) that would enable the electric company to optimize operation of its power generation and transmission facilities thus reducing costs. Fourth, begin the reduction of the high losses in the electricity distribution system. Eifth, facilitate the development of independent power producers (IPPs), with the initial plants probably being mini-hydro power plants. Finally, facilitate the eventual reintegration of ESM into UCPTE by improving its system controls. B. The discussion of benefits below is broken down into the three components. However, the components are interrelated in that, for example, the improved energy management system (EMS) will allow ESM to make better use of the increased hydropower capacity and production and vice versa. Thus system improvement may be greater than the sum of the parts. 5.02 In general this analysis is carried out using international market-based prices and costs. Taxes are excluded. Shadow prices could have been used for labor costs (see para. 5.14) but were not since they are not available. A sensitivity analysis assuming a lower real cost for labor was carried out (see para. 5.16). The analysis excludes the Swiss grant of 5 mil SF which was subject to a separate analysis conducted for the Government of Switzerland by EEF. A. HYDROPOWER PLANT REHABILITATION 5.03 The hydropower plants according to EEF are facing "equipment dilapidation" due to age as well as obsolescence. As a result their generation, capacity , reliability and safety are decreasing. Rehabilitation of these hydro-power plants is the least cost means of providing the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia with peaking capacity. Furthermore, as these plants continue to deteriorate from age they will become rapidly more unreliable depriving the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia of its required peaking capacity and leading to expensive outages. The only near term alternative, new gas fired peaking units, would be much more expensive and increase the country's already high reliance on imported energy. In emergencies power can sometimes be obtained from the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's neighbors. However, this power cannot be relied on since many of the neighboring power systems have serious problems and political relationships in the Balkans are uncertain. 5.04 The main benefits from rehabilitation of the hydropower plants are thus: 1) increased hydropower generating capacity leading to improved primary and secondary regulation; 2) increased hydropower generation; 3) reduction in hydropower plant operating costs; and 4) reduced likelihood of hydropower plant and system outages. 5.05 Increased Capaciy. The reconstruction of the turbines at the hydropower plants will add significantly to the generating capacity of these plants by increasing the efficiency with which the water from the penstocks is used. This additional capacity will add to system reserves and improve primary and secondary regulation. There are two estimates of the increase in capacity. ESM has estimated that the total capacity increase will be about 40 MW while the consultant, EEF, has estimated that the total increase in capacity will be 31 MW. ESM and EEF use different assumptions but the assumptions used by EEF are more conservative. In order to be conservative, for the purpose of this analysis an increase of 31 MW has been used. If this capacity were to be built on a
 31 greenfield basis it would probably cost around $1580/Kw, based on the average cost per Kw of 16 proposed new hydropower plants in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. (See The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Energy Review, Report 15313-Mk, Appendix B.) This would imply a replacement value of this additional capacity of about $49 million. However, in market economies this system reserve capacity can often be contracted from other power systems. The Macedonians have not contracted reserve capacity but from previous work done on the adjacent Bulgarian Electricity System, (See Staff Appraisal Report Bulgaria Energy Project, Report 11250- BUL, page 38), it is estimated that this reserve capacity can be contracted for about $100,000/MW/year. If this price is used for the additional Macedonian capacity it gives it a value of $3.1 Million per year. 5.06 Increased Generafion. The increase in hydropower generation due to increased efficiency of the turbines is estimated by EEF 13.7 Gwh per year. This is a gain of 1.9% on average for the six plants and assumes an average year with 730 Gwh of hydropower generation from these plants. Again this is a conservative assumption, since this 1.9% gain in efficiency would have led to a 24.4 Gwh increase in generation last year and 16.3 Gwh increase in generation using the average of the past three years. This additional power would be largely peaking power and generated in the winter when the demand for power in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is at its peak due to the heating load. It would replace either power generated from thermal power plants in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia or power swaps with neighbors. This additional power has been valued at 5 US cents/Kwh which is both a measure of consumers willingness to pay (See para. 2.17.) and in the range of estimates of Long Run Marginal Cost. (See The Forrmer Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Energy Review, para. 5.21.) Thus the value of this additional power, without any addition for consumer's surplus, would be $ 685,000 per year. 5.07 O iig Cot. The investments in the hydropower plants will significantly reduce operating costs, mainly repair costs, by replacing worn out or obsolete equipment. Current equipment is expensive to maintain with the cost of repairs (mostly spare parts) amounting to about $ 2 million per year. EEF has estimated that with the rehabilitation of the plants the cost of repairs could be reduced to about $ 1 million per year for a net gain of $ 1.0 million per year. It is assumed that this would continue for 10 years and then that repair costs would again start to rise, reaching their current level in 20 years. 5.08 Outags. Because of the age of the equipment, outages of hydropower generating units are expected to increase rapidly unless these units are rehabilitated. As a first approximation, EEF assumed that one power plant out of six would be out of operation one month per year if no rehabilitation were undertaken and that this risk would be reduced by two thirds if the plants were rehabilitated. This implies that as a result of the rehabilitation the lost generation from outages of hydropower plants would be reduced by about 7 Gwh per year. If in fact this electricity was unserved energy (i.e. it resulted in brown outs or black outs) the value would be very high. Typical values for unserved energy, used in planning studies in the US are in the range of $1.00 to $4.00 per Kwh.
 32 ($1000-$4000/Mwh) and in planning studies in Bulgaria values of 30 US cents/Kwh or more are used. However, we have valued this electricity at 5 US cents/Kwh as explained above which gives this benefit a value of $350,000 per year. This assumes that the electricity would have been replaced by electricity generated from thermal power plants or by swaps with neighboring countries. 5.09 Total benefits, Total estimated benefits thus are about $5.13 million per year, using quite conservative assumptions. The Economic Rate of Return ( ERR) on this component would then be about 17%. Including the 18% contingencies in the capital costs reduces the ERR to 14%. If less conservative assumptions are used, for example assuming the outages described in para 5.08 above would lead to unserved energy valued at $500/Mwh ( see para 5.13), then the ERR would be over 30%. The base case of estimate of 17%, however, appears to be a reasonable. B. COMPLETION OF ENERGY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM 5.10 The Energy Management System ( EMS) will increase efficiency, reliability and security of supply in the power system. There are no good alternatives, and without the EMS the power system would have higher operating and maintenance costs and need a higher reserve margin to minimize loss of load probability. 5.11 The quantifiable benefits of a modern Energy Management System (EMS) are derived from four main areas: (i) generation scheduling benefits; (ii) benefits from improved system reliability and security; (iii) operation and maintenance cost savings; and (iv) benefits from sharing of common spinning reserves in a large interconnected power system, such as that of Western European Power Interconnected System (UCPTE). The extent of these benefits depends on the structure and size of the power system. 5.12 Generation Scheduling Benefits. The benefits arise from on-line economic dispatch, both of units under real-time control as well as those that are controlled manually, and economic dispatch of spinning reserve. The main benefit is fuel savings. Large utilities with significant variations in fuel costs have claimed savings of 1% to 4% of total annual fuel cost. For ESM, the generation component of the electric system is dominated by the three units (3x 225 MW) of the Bitola lignite-fired power plant. On any given operating day, the Bitola units may account for more than 75% of the power output. As a result, ESM does not stand to gain as much from the opportunity for exploiting diversification of generating resources, as larger electric utilities can gain from Economic Dispatch and Unit Commitment programs. However, the opportunity does exist to receive some benefit from hydro-thermal scheduling (including Unit Commitment), optimal power flow, loss minimalization, and on-line Economic Dispatch. For the ESM system, estimated savings are expected to be about 1% of total annual fuel cost or $ 365,000 per year.
 33 5.13 Benefits from Improved Reliability of Operations. Utilities generally have reported gains in overall system reliability resulting from the implementation of an EMS. Benefits arise from a decrease in outages due to an increase in overall security of electricity supply. This in turn results from improved control over power flow through the transmission network, and faster response and restoration after a black-out. In addition to the revenue gains from fewer outages there are social benefits reflecting the indirect cost to the economy of power outages. The Bank's consultant on this component as well as ESM have estimated that an improvement in reliability of 0.025%, or 2.2 hours per year, can be achieved by installing an EMS. In putting a value on this reduction in potential system outages, it is assumed that these potential system outages would occur during the winter since this is when the system is under greatest pressure due to the heating load .In the winter a potential outage of 2.2 hours would imply a potential loss in consumption of about 2.2 million Kwh. As pointed out above, estimates in the US of the costs of unserved energy are high but given the lower levels of income and GNP in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, a lower value for unserved energy should apply. Therefore for the purposes of this analysis a value of 50 US cents/Kwh ($500/Mwh) was used. ( It should be noted, however, that an analysis made for the earlier EMS Project for the Yugoslav Federation indicated a much higher value- $2000/Mwh for unserved energy. However, this was an estimate for all of Yugoslavia, not the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia which was one of the poorer parts, and the estimate was made in much better economic circumstances) This value of $500/Mwh for unserved energy implies in turn that the reduction in potential system outages resulting from the EMS would be worth about $ 1.1 Million per year. 5.14 Benefits from Qperation and Maintenanc * . ESM can gain greatly from the efficiencies that an Energy Management System offers, particularly in substation operations. In the United Sates, many substations are "operator-less" and "crew-less" and are served by mobile crews. ESM has calculated a personnel benefit based on the reduction of substation staffing from 170 to 70 staff. Similar benefits could be realized from reduction in power plant operating staff. This implies that ESM's staff could be reduced by about 200 persons as a result of the EMS. Given that the typical employee costs ESM $6700 per year this implies a potential savings of about $1.34 Million per year. (This estimate of $6700 per worker is the financial savings for ESM; the economic benefit to the country from redeploying workers over time may be less though how much less is not clear.) These savings are unlikely to be implemented immediately and but still they could be implemented over a few year through a reduction in new hires. 5.15 Other Benefit. These are savings that would arise from the connection of the Macedonian network to the UCPTE network and the sharing of common spinning reserves which would reduce the requirement for ESM to have independent spinning reserves. A good EMS would significantly improve the ability of ESM to reconnect to UCPTE. Estimates of these benefits are currently not included in the project benefits, due to the current uncertainty about the timing of the reconnection to the UCPTE system. (See para. 2.13.)

Including contingencies in capital costs decreases the rate of return to 25%. If it were assumed that the economic benefit from reducing the work force at ESM and employing new workers elsewhere is only one half the financial benefit (i.e. $3350 per person instead of $6700) and using capital cost including contingencies, then the ERR would be reduced to 19 % - still a very good real rate of return. However, the calculations of the ERR were based on recent Macedonian experience which has been one of relative dryness. 5.22 EMS Cgmponent. Due to the high technology nature of the project, there are risks associated with the fact this technology is continuously evolving and changing rapidly. The risks in the distribution component are quite small and it appears to be attractive as a small separate component. However, the full impact of this component would occur only if ESM rehabilitates the entire distribution system. ESM will need outside funding for such a major distribution project and has discussed with the Bank the possibility of funding such a future project. F. PROIECT SUSIAIABILITY 5.24 The project is entirely sustainable as long as the equipment is properly maintained and the needed repairs and updating are carried out. This is in turn likely to depend largely on the level of electricity prices. If prices are maintained at an adequate level ESM has both the funds and the incentive to repair and update the equipment. However, if electricity prices were to decline to the point that they only covered cash costs or below then ESM would cut back on maintenance and the equipment would deteriorate. It is in the interest of the Government and ESM to maintain an adequate level of electricity prices and this is reinforced by the Bank's covenants. With adequate upkeep the hydroelectric plants can then produce electricity almost indefinitely since their fuel (water) is renewable.

doc.abstracts: The Power System Improvement Project for Macedonia aims to achieve the following: 1) increase the efficiency of hydropower generation; 2) expand the generating capacity of the major hydropower plants through rehabilitation; 3) increase system operating efficiency and enable the electric company to optimize operation of its power generation and transmission facilities through reducing costs; 4) begin reducing high losses in the electricity distribution system; 5) facilitate the development of independent power producers, with the initial plants being mini-hydropower plants; and 6) help reintegrate Macedonia's power company (ESM) into UCPTE (the Western European Electricity network) by improving its system controls. The project consists of three components: 1) rehabilitating the six largest hydropower plants in Macedonia, which represent 91 percent of the country's hydropower capacity; 2) improving the energy management system including modernizing data acquisition and installing remote controls for the power system, completing the dispatch center, and improving telecommunications; and 3) beginning the rehabilitation of the electricity distribution system.
